ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Critical analysis of historical materials. Challenging long-standing societal structures. I really appreciated the exploration of what it means to live in a colonialized space.
I learned a lot about the complicated binaries and spectrums of tradition and modernity and the pluralities of medicine in South Asia over time.
I learned a lot about the history of South Asian Medicine, but also tradition and modernity in a more general context in science, medicine, and history.
Application of history analytical skills, reading analysis, and critical analysis

I learnt a lot about the history of traditional medicine in South Asia, coupled with the history of biomedicine. It was a great history of medicine class that taught me skills in non-Western history of medicine.
I learned about the complex realities of history and medicine in South Asia. I learned about the interaction of different culture and how that manifests in the medical systems we see today.
History of medicine in South Asia, and ideas of tradition, modernity, and how to critically think about historical sources and perspectives
This course was a very interesting analysis of aspects of tradition and modernity in medicine in South Asia. I gained essential skills in historical thinking and analysis.
Lots of relevant content on health in South Asia (that is actually useful for the field), practice reading tough literature
Historical reasoning, understanding of medical pluralism, perspectives on south asian medical traditions vs biomedicine, conceptions of care and well-being
The complex history of medicine in South Asia.

disrupting grand narratives and binaries: religion and pre-modern south asia, medical pluralism, orientialism's influence on ayurveda, scientific revolution as a created construct, frameworks to understand therapeutic efficacy

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Very strong! Lots of supplementary materials to engage with. Required reading material brought forth meaningful conversation.

There are a lot of strengths! Kiran is so nice and flexible, the workload each week is very manageable and readings are generally interesting, and class discussions are also interesting and relevant. I can't think of any weaknesses.

Strengths: Professor Kumbhar and his clear care for students and making the classroom environment a safe space where everyone feels welcome to participate. The assignments and readings reflected a great deal of thought in the goals of what we should take away from the class, and I learned so much from my peers and the small group environment. Weaknesses: none.

Strengths: very interesting material, cool readings, great professor. I liked the midterm assignment
Weaknesses: it often felt like we were talking about the same themes every week (modernity and tradition). I would have loved more focus on other themes as well that may be related to the main theme of the course -- our readings touched on a lot of other ideas that I would have loved to discuss more in depth.

The strengths were that Professor Kumbhar was very amicable and always available for extra help and questions.
No major weaknesses, maybe providing a clearer rubric for the midterm essay and review essay. Additionally, it would have been helpful if we were given a short lecture on the context/history of the time period we were reading, just so we had a solid foundation for discussion. The discussion sometimes fell flat, therefore discussion questions before hand would be great to start the conversation flowing.

Readings were fantastic! I would have never come across them without this class, and it really opened a new world of thinking about non-Western history of medicine. Kiran Kumbhar is also such a knowledgeable professor and gem of a human being. Sometimes the material was a little dense and could be repetitive, but it was overall a fantastic course.

This course was very well structured, it had great readings and I really appreciate Professor Kumbhar for including other forms of media like music videos, documentaries, social medial posts, and lay journalism. The use of powerpoints and opening activities to set the tone for class was great. The writing assignments were both academically relevant and personally fulfilling. The final assignment was good for building analysis skills that can be used in future classes and daily life.
This was a great class! The professor made the environment very engaging, and the material was very interesting
The course is very good at teaching you a broad and general understanding of various aspects of tradition and modernity.
The readings in this course were incredible, but I think the in class discussions could sometimes feel a little unstructured
Very well-structured.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. Very engaging and challenges the mind.

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to another student. It was really useful in helping me unwind my prior conceptions regarding biomedicine, colonialism, and South Asia. It is super insightful and helps you become a more critical thinker. While most of the focus is on South Asia, some aspects of the course allow you to learn about other regions in the Global South (like the midterm paper and final paper).
Yes! This course was absolutely incredible and I really enjoyed it. If you are interested in the history of medicine in South Asia, you should definitely take this class.
Yes! Fun course with great professor. Super interesting material.
Definitely recommend this course to get a deeper understanding of the binary between traditional and modern medicine in South Asia.

Yes! It was great! It's pretty rare in the HSHM department that you get to take courses that focus on the non-Western history of science. This was a great course to delve right into that material. The material is cool history of medicine and traditional medical forms that you can really not study anywhere else. Also, Kiran Kumbhar is fantastic!

I would only recommend it to student who are particularly interested in non-western medical models. If a student does not have interest in this area they might find it uninteresting or become lost in all of the detailed articles.
Yes! It was one of my favorite classes, not super stressful but still very informative
I would definitely recommend this course to another student as it was very intellectually interesting and I was able to learn a plethora of topics about medicine in South Asia.
Yes, very interesting and in depth discussions
Absolutely, and you dont need to be premed to gain value from the course
yes! great way to learn about dicourse between south asian medical traditions and biomedicine and an introduction to critically studying south asia.
Yes, great insights!

absolutely! Prof Kumbhar has so much experience on the ground and creates a lovely learning environment. Each week's readings are carefully curated for an engaging discussion and to surprise you by complicating the traditional narratives of history. You'll enjoy every class!
YES; this is one of my favorite classes at Yale.
